container-title: P. julianettii is often considered to be the cultivated form of P. brosimos
note: cf. Lemonnier 2002 in which both are referred to as ‘semi-domesticated’). Cook raises the possibility that P. iwen is ‘in-between’ the cultivated P. julianettii and the wild P. brosimos, since the Amungme of Irian Jaya consider it to be the ‘uncle’ of both (1999: 96; cf. Stone 1984).
title: types of P. brosimos, as well as the uncertain taxonomic status of P. iwen, the classification and anthropic associations of members of this high-altitude Pandanus spp. complex remain to be fully elucidated (Denham 2007c). In historical records, these Pandanus spp. are noted as major sources of fat and protein for some highland groups; they can be collected, dried/ smoked and stored for consumption later in the year, for example, Baruya (Lemonnier 2002

container-title: Cook notes that cultivation of P. julianettii occurs as low as 1200 m among the Amungme in West Papua
title: Under present climatic conditions, Bourke (2017; see Table 5.2) described the normal altitudinal ranges of P. brosimos and P. julianettii as 2400–3100 m and 1800–2600 m, respectively, and the extremes as 1800–3300 m and 1450–2800 m, respectively

author.particle: reports that L.J. Brass found fruiting

note: brosimos (usually from 2400 m upwards) and lowland P. conoideus (usually from 1700 m downwards). Pandanus antaresensis, also referred to as karuka, fills this altitudinal and ecological gap; it usually grows from 1000–2350 m and has an extreme altitudinal range of 850–2460 m (Bourke 2017; see Hyndman 1984). Today, P. antaresensis is only eaten by
title: julianettii at 1300 m. The fruit-producing Pandanus conoideus (marita) has a normal altitudinal range of 0–1700 m, an extreme range of 0–1980 m
and is an important dietary item between 500 m and 1400 m
